I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Viet Nam has requested technical assistance (TA) from the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to enhance absorptive capacity and efficiency in implementing official 
development assistance (ODA) projects and programs. Although the TA was not included in the 
country  strategy  and  program  2007–20101 endorsed  by  the  Board  in  October  2006,  the 
Government  communicated  the  TA’s  high  priority  to  the  January  2007  Country  Program 
Confirmation Mission.2 The Fact-Finding Mission was conducted in June 2007 and reached an 
understanding with the Government on the TA’s impact and outcome, scope, cost and financing, 
implementation arrangements, and terms of reference for the consultants. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Viet  Nam’s  recent  socioeconomic  development  has  been  remarkable.  Poverty 
decreased from 58.1% in 1993 to 18.1% in 2006, and average per capita income increased 
from $288 to $712 during the same period.3 Further reduction of poverty incidence to 10%–11% 
by 2010 is a goal of the Government’s Socio-Economic Development Plan for 2006–2010.4 This 
plan aims to (i) accelerate and sustain economic growth and development; (ii) significantly 
improve  people’s  material,  cultural,  and  spiritual  life;  (iii)  create  the  foundations  to  boost 
industrialization and modernization and gradually develop a knowledge-based economy; and 
(iv) enhance Viet Nam’s status in the region and in the world. 
 
3.  While  committed  national  efforts  have  enhanced  the  country’s  socioeconomic 
development, various types of ODA from multilateral and bilateral external agencies also made 
significant contributions. ODA loans helped to finance key infrastructure, social services, and 
agriculture  development  projects,  while  ODA-financed  TAs  helped  to  introduce  new  skills, 
international best practices, and modern technology. ODA commitments over the past 5 years 
totaled about $11.1 billion. However, only about $7.8 billion was disbursed, substantially less 
than the target of $9.0 billion.  
 
4.  As  Viet  Nam  expedites  its  reforms  and  socioeconomic  development  with  large 
investment targets, ODA partners are prepared to increase their level of assistance. Accordingly, 
a December 2006 consultative group (CG) meeting witnessed a record-high ODA pledge of 
$4.4 billion. However, the country’s absorptive capacity remains a serious concern. Although it 
is recognized that the ODA projects and programs usually achieve their development objectives 
and the outcomes are satisfactory and sustainable, most projects and programs experience 
substantial implementation delays. Slow project implementation has significant consequences 
on the achievement of Viet Nam’s development objectives, as well as on the cost of the 
investments. 
 
5.  External  agencies  have  repeatedly  presented  this  issue  to  the  Government.  The 
Government drafted a strategic framework to mobilize and use ODA more effectively, and is 
updating the legal and institutional framework governing ODA. A decree on ODA utilization and 
management (Decree 131/2006/ND-CP), approved in November 2006, represents part of the 
Government’s efforts. Decree 131 provides the delegation of approval authority on projects and

programs to the line ministries, agencies, or provinces, reducing project implementation delays. 
However, the specific steps necessary to implement the decentralization policy, stipulated by 
Decree 131, must be developed based on the detailed Implementing Circulars that are being 
finalized. Once these are issued, there will be a need to help develop capacity, particularly that 
of the provinces. Clarification at each project level on internal approval authority and procedures 
under Decree 131 will also be necessary to minimize project implementation delays during the 
transition period. 
 
6.  The  2006  Country  Portfolio  Review  Mission  (CPRM),  conducted  in  November–
December 2006, was concerned with the deterioration of 2006 disbursement performance. 
Disbursements in 2006 totaled $184.1 million; in 2005, it was $223.7 million. The action plan 
developed  by  the  2006  CPRM  includes:  (i)  simplification  and  decentralization  of  the 
Government’s approval procedures; (ii) acceleration of loan processing and reduction of time 
from loan approval to signing and effectiveness; (iii) implementation of advance actions to 
reduce start-up delays; (iv) preparation of realistic project implementation plans and projections 
for contract awards and disbursements; (v) cost estimation in line with market rates; and (vi) 
improved structure, operation, and capacity of project management units (PMU). 
 
7.  The  need  for  these  actions  were  further  reinforced  by  the  Fifth  Joint  Portfolio 
Performance Review (JPPR V), jointly conducted in March–May 2007 by the Government’s 
ODA Inter-Ministerial Task Force (IMTF) and the Five Banks, i.e., ADB, Agence Française de 
Développement, Japan Bank for International Cooperation, Kreditanstalt für Wiederaufbau, and 
the World Bank.5 To achieve rapid results, actions that can be implemented quickly without any 
revision of existing legal framework were identified as the “ODA Fast Track”. Implementation of 
the ODA Fast Track is expected to lead to substantial and immediate reduction of project 
implementation delays. 
 
8.  Actions identified under the ODA Fast Track are as follows: 
 
(i)  Streamline project preparation documents and process between the Government 
and the Five Banks including: (a) harmonizing the Project Detailed Outline of the 
Government and the Project Concept Note of the donors; (b) institutionalizing the 
common Feasibility Study (FS) Guidelines; and (c) synchronizing processes with 
upstream  approval  of  the  ODA  Requesting  List  by  the  Prime  Minister  and 
approval of FS by line ministries/agencies prior to loan negotiations. 
(ii)  Include  in  the  Project  Detailed  Outline  the  source  of  funding  for  project 
preparation (from the Government counterpart funds, preparation grants and TAs, 
and other project preparation facilities). 
(iii)  Delink the requirement of Basic Design from the approval of FS by revising 
Decree 112. Until then, in the short-term, this requirement should not apply to 
ODA projects and programs. 
(iv)  Base  the  approval  of  program/sector  loan  on  general  program  framework, 
including allow delegated management of program/sector loans and consider 
applying these retroactively for ongoing loans. 
(v)  Identify the Project Owner for all ongoing and planned Five Banks’ projects in 
accordance with Decree 131. 
(vi)  Ensure  smooth  transfer  of  staff  involved  in  preparation  stage  to  PMUs  in 
implementation stage and provide necessary resources for project preparation. 
                                                
5  In 1999 JPPR began to identify common portfolio performance constraints among the Five Banks.

3 
(vii)  Conduct advance action by allowing the implementation of appropriate activities 
such as procurement, consulting services, resettlement, and other key project 
start-up activities in the period commencing from FS approved by the competent 
agencies to the timing the loan agreements become effective. 
(viii)  Identify clearly remaining gaps and differences between the Government and 
donor procurement regulations by: (a) providing clear guidance/training during 
the project launch to Project Owners, as well as auditors and inspectors, on how 
to deal with the major inconsistencies; and (b) ensuring awareness that in case 
of  conflicts  between  the  Government  and  donor  regulations,  the  agreed 
procedures in the legal agreement prevail. 
(ix)  Use Article 3.3 of the Procurement Law for ODA projects and programs to: (a) 
establish a system whereby costs are controlled at the overall project level rather 
than  on  individual  packages;  (b)  allow  winning  bids  to  exceed  the  approval 
estimated price of the procurement package (exception to Articles 37 and 38); 
and (c) use the market reference prices to establish cost estimates. 
(x)  Revise the restrictions on consultancy rates on ODA projects and programs so 
that market rates can be paid for high quality consultancy services. 
(xi)  Accelerate payments by clarifying the roles and responsibilities of State Treasury 
and Banks, streamlining processes and establishing business standards for the 
checking process. 
(xii)  Speed up resettlement activities by piloting the establishment of a separately 
funded land acquisition/resettlement project, implemented in accordance with the 
Government’s and donors’ harmonized social safeguard policies and guidelines. 
 
9.  The IMTF reported the findings and recommendations of the JPPR V to the Prime 
Minister of Viet Nam. The Prime Minister instructed the IMTF to (i) collaborate with relevant 
agencies and the Five Banks to select several specific recommendations proposed by the  
JPPR V for his approval by August 2007; and (ii) collaborate with the Five Banks to develop an 
action plan for 2007–2009, based on the outcomes and recommendations of the JPPR V, 
aiming to improve ODA project and program implementation and to disburse $11 billion during 
2006–2010. 
 
10.  The Five Banks are committed to helping the Government implement the ODA Fast 
Track as instructed by the Prime Minister. The proposed TA will form a part of the Five Banks’ 
joint efforts to enable the Government to overcome various difficulties at the project level under 
the transition to the new legal and institutional framework for ODA. It will also achieve rapid and 
tangible improvements in the portfolio performance of ODA projects and programs.  
 
11.  The Government intends to promote social support mobilization in public investment 
projects and programs. Social support mobilization is expected to be beneficial particularly to 
activities that require extensive public awareness, e.g., human immunodeficiency virus/acquired 
immunodeficiency syndrome (HIV/AIDS) prevention and traffic safety campaigns. The proposed 
TA  will  also  help  the  Government  to  pilot  social  support  mobilization  and  prepare 
recommendations to expand it. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE

12.  The TA will assist the Government in strengthening the absorptive capacity of ODA and 
improving efficiency in preparation, implementation, and monitoring and evaluation of ODA

4   
projects and programs under the new framework governing ODA under Decree 131. The TA’s 
expected outcome will be improved performance of ADB’s portfolio in Viet Nam, as indicated by 
improvements in contract awards and disbursements and the reduction of start-up delays. The 
TA will also contribute to the ongoing joint efforts by the Government and development partners 
towards  harmonization  under  the  framework  of  the  Hanoi  Core  Statement  (HCS)  on  Aid 
Effectiveness. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The TA will help the Government in (i) conducting in-depth analysis of the bottlenecks to 
implementing the selected actions of the ODA Fast Track,6 (ii) specifying the steps necessary to 
implement each action, and (iii) identifying the responsible parties and time frame to implement 
each  action.  Considering  that  the  ADB  portfolio  is  part  of  the  country’s  overall  ODA,  a  
well-coordinated  approach  with  all  principal  stakeholders,  i.e.,  the  Government  and  its 
development partners, will be applied in implementing the TA. 
 
14.  The actions to be covered by the TA will include (i) identification of the line agency, 
project owner, and PMU, as outlined in Decree 131, for each ongoing or planned project 
financed by ADB; (ii) advance contracting for procurement and consultants, resettlement, and 
other key project start-up activities; (iii) smooth transfer of staff involved in the preparation stage 
to PMUs in the implementation stage; (iv) use of the aligned monitoring tool and the portfolio 
monitoring tool; (v) harmonization of the social and environmental safeguard policies of the 
Government  and  development  partners;  (vi)  capacity  strengthening  for  the  line  ministries, 
agencies,  or  provinces  to  assume  new  responsibilities  and  requirements  regarding  project 
administration and management in the context of Decree 131; and (vii) piloting social support 
mobilization and preparation of recommendations for further expansion. 
 
15.  The TA will undertake a series of workshops and seminars to consult and disseminate 
the TA findings to relevant stakeholders. The TA will also assist the Government in conducting 
analytical works to prepare necessary inputs to important meetings, e.g., CG meetings. 
 
16.  Capacity building will be an important part of the TA activities. Training programs for 
officials of central Government agencies and local governments, as well as PMUs, will be 
conducted regularly on ADB’s procedures and requirements related to project implementation, 
including (i) management of ordinary capital resources; (ii) cost and benefit analysis; (iii) new 
policies, instruments, and modes; and (iv) financial management. Training of trainers will be 
emphasized to ensure sustainability. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $800,000 equivalent, with the Government 
requesting that ADB finance the equivalent of $700,000. The details of the cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. ADB’s TA funding program will provide a grant to finance the 
TA, and the Government will finance the balance of $100,000 by providing counterpart staff, 
office space, furniture, administrative support services and logistics, and necessary data.  
 
                                                
6  The Five Banks will share responsibilities in helping the Government to implement the ODA Fast Track.

5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The Foreign Economic Relations Department (FERD) of the Ministry of Planning and 
Investment will be the Executing Agency for the TA. FERD will provide overall guidance for TA 
implementation,  ensure  interagency  coordination,  and  issue  appropriate  directives  and 
decisions. FERD and ADB will ensure close coordination among Government agencies and 
development partners, e.g., IMTF and the Five Banks, through existing forum. FERD also will 
conduct training courses on the implementation procedures and requirements of ADB-financed 
projects and programs. The State Bank of Viet Nam, by request, will conduct some special 
training courses on ADB project implementation at a total cost not exceeding $50,000. 
 
19.  The  TA  will  require  8  person-months  of  international  consulting  services  and  
60 person-months of national consulting services. The international consultants will provide 
expertise  in  institutional  development  (3  person-months)  and  capacity  building  
(3  person-months).  The  national  consultants  will  have  expertise  in  legal  aspects  
(6 person-months), public training (6 person-months), economics (10 person-months), social 
development  (10  person-months),  environmental  matters  (6  person-months),  social  and 
resettlement matters (6 person-months), and monitoring and evaluation (6 person-months). Two 
person-months of international and 10 person-months of national consultants are allocated to 
activities that are not yet identified to ensure flexibility in the TA’s implementation. ADB will 
engage consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended from time to time). All international and national consultants will be selected and 
contracted individually. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. The 
consulting services required for the TA will include, but will not necessarily be limited to, the 
services  described  in  this  appendix.  The  consultants  may  augment  the  tasks  outlined  as 
required  by  FERD  and  ADB  to  improve  the  TA’s  overall  quality.  Local  nongovernment 
organizations  will  be  consigned  to  pilot  social  support  mobilization  using  consultants’ 
qualification selection. FERD may procure equipment through shopping in accordance with 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). Upon completion of the 
TA, this equipment will be transferred to FERD. 
 
20.  The TA will be implemented over 3 years, from September 2007 to August 2010. The 
following major reports are required from each consultant: (i) an inception report describing the 
detailed  work  program  within  2  weeks  of  commencement  of  the  assignment,  (ii)  progress 
reports every 2 months during the assignment, (iii) a draft final report describing the detailed TA 
findings 1 month before completion of the assignment, and (iv) a final report 2 weeks after 
receiving comments from the Government and ADB on the draft final report. Tripartite meetings 
will be held with the Government, ADB, and consultants to discuss the TA reports, which will be 
prepared in English and translated into Vietnamese. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for Enhancing Official Development 
Assistance Absorptive Capacity and Efficiency, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The professional positions, person-months, and activities for the required positions are 
as follows: 
 
A.  Institutional  Development  Specialist  (international,  3  person-months)  and 
Legal Specialist (national, 6 person-months) 
 
2.  The activities of these positions include but are not limited to helping the Government 
undertake the following:  
       
(i)  define the roles and responsibilities of the line agency, project owner, and project 
management  unit  (PMU);  prepare  material  regarding  these  roles  and 
responsibilities  for  project  stakeholders;  and  develop  and  document  detailed 
procedures to instruct the project stakeholders on how to identify the line agency, 
project owner, and PMU for their own projects; 
 
(ii)  instruct project stakeholders to identify the line agency, project owner, and PMU; 
consolidate their responses; and clarify the line agency, project owner, and PMU 
as documented in Decree 131 and its Circulars for each ADB-financed ongoing 
or planned project; 
 
(iii)  investigate  the  Government’s  administrative  mechanism  to  approve  advance 
contracting for procurement and consultants including:  
 
(a)  preparation of the terms of reference, shortlisting, request for proposals, 
and evaluation of proposals for consultants;  
 
(b)  prequalification  of  contractors,  tendering,  and  bid  evaluation  for  civil 
works packages; and  
 
(c)  preparation of tender documents to procure materials and equipment; 
 
(iv)  investigate  the  Government’s  administrative  mechanism  to  allocate  adequate 
counterpart  funds  before  loan  effectiveness  to  ensure  that  the  PMUs  are 
established and functional to undertake advance contracting; 
 
(v)  develop  and  document  detailed  procedures  on  implementing  advance 
contracting for procurement and consultants and pilot implementation of advance 
contracting for selected ADB-financed new projects; 
 
(vi)  revise detailed procedures and documentation, if necessary, based on the results 
of  piloting;  prepare  instructions for the  project  stakeholders  on  implementing 
advance  contracting  for  procurement  and  consultants;  and  apply  advance 
contracting to all ADB-financed new projects; 
 
(vii)  clarify responsibilities and identify the coordinator of cross-provincial projects; 
 
(viii)  review  Decree  131  and  its  Circulars  from  the  perspective  of  sector  loan 
implementation to ensure delegated management of subproject appraisal and 
selection;

(ix)  clarify  the  preparation  and  implementation  arrangements  for  ordinary  capital 
resources loans; and 
 
(x)  study  the  possibility  of  using  loan  funds  for  capacity  building  and  project 
management when sufficient grant funds are not available. 
 
B.  Capacity  Building  Specialist  (international,  3  person-months)  and  Public 
Training Specialist (national, 6 person-months) 
 
3.  The activities of these positions include but are not limited to helping the Government 
undertake the following:  
 
(i)  assess the capacity-strengthening needs of the line ministries, agencies and/or 
provinces  to  assume  new  responsibilities  and  requirements  for  project 
administration and management under Decree 131; develop training programs 
and material for this purpose; and conduct pilot training for the selected line 
ministries, agencies, and/or provinces; 
 
(ii)  modify the training programs and materials, if necessary, based on the pilot 
training’s results and prepare a proposal for a nationwide capacity-strengthening 
program with timeframes and financial requirements; 
 
(iii)  analyze the bottlenecks and clarify the steps needed within the Government to 
involve  the  same  qualified  staff  in  project  preparation  and  ensuing  loan 
implementation to ensure continuity; 
 
(iv)  develop detailed procedures to involve the same staff for project preparation and 
implementation  and  pilot  implementation  for  the  selected  ADB-financed  new 
projects; 
 
(v)  revise detailed procedures, if necessary, based on the piloting results; prepare 
instructions for the project stakeholders on involving the same staff for project 
preparation and implementation; and apply to all ADB-financed new projects; and 
 
(vi)  provide a comprehensive project management training program for PMU staff on 
ADB’s  requirements  for  procurement,  financial  management,  monitoring  and 
evaluation, and safeguard policies at the beginning of project implementation.

undertake the following:  
 
(i)  review  the  country’s  general  economic  development  situation  and  specific 
progress and achievements of the Socio-Economic Development Plan for 2006–

D.  Social Development Specialist (national, 10 person-months) 
 
5.  The activities of this position include but are not limited to helping the Government

E.  Environmental Specialist (national, 6 person-months)

undertake the following: 
 
(i)  update information on the Government’s and donor agencies’ requirements for 
an environmental impact assessment; 
 
(ii)  develop a detailed workplan to achieve the targets on environmental safeguards 
under the Hanoi Core Statement (HCS) that incorporate:
